title-group.article-title: Meso-scale and multicontinuum modeling of a triaxial braided textile composite

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wyoming, USA

author-notes.corresp: Mark Garnich, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wyoming, 1000 E. University Ave., Laramie, WY 82071, USA. Email: garnich@uwyo.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Accurately predicting failure in woven composites requires knowledge of the stress states within the meso-scale structure of the fabric reinforcement. Multicontinuum technology provides a computationally efficient way of extracting constituent stresses and strains from a structural-level finite element analysis. This study investigates the value in extending the capabilities of multicontinuum technology to materials with complex heterogeneity that could benefit from the definition of many constituents. To determine the feasibility of this extension, a meso-scale finite element model of a triaxial braid was developed and used as a test case. The model’s predictions of initial matrix failure were in good agreement with the limited experimental data. Also, trends in initial failure predictions for multi-axial load cases are in agreement with physically intuitive expectations. These results show promise for the success of future research in extending multicontinuum technology for application to composites with complex multiscale heterogeneity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: One defining characteristic of textile-reinforced composites versus unidirectional laminates is the existence of an additional, distinct hierarchical level of scale. On the micro-scale, the fiber diameter provides the characteristic length scale. Fibers are generally assembled into a tow or yarn consisting of thousands of fibers. The cross-sectional dimensions of such fiber bundles provide the characteristic length at the meso-scale. These yarns are woven together in some distinct pattern and impregnated with a matrix material as part of a manufacturing process, thus creating a structure at the macro-scale. Herein, the term yarn is used universally to refer to the bundles of fibers in the braid architecture; whether dry or impregnated.

One complication that arises from the use of textile composites is an increase in the complexity of the analyses required to predict composite properties and failure. Various approaches1–9 have been devised to deal with the complexity. Many of these studies have involved failure analysis.3–9 However, with the exception of Kwon and Altekin,5 these studies involving failure analysis have been confined to the meso-scale. Full-scale, structural level problems require a way to link the results provided by the meso-scale model to the structural scale. Multicontinuum technology (MCT) is a computationally efficient method for bridging the scales from micro to meso to macro. In this approach, constituent properties are used to obtain composite properties through the use of a micromechanics model. Then, through the assumption that everywhere in the composite, a continuum field exists for each constituent, an analytical relationship between the composite stresses and strains and the constituent stresses and strains is achieved. During a structural-level analysis, constituent stresses and strains at a point can be obtained independent of further micromechanics modeling. MCT has already been demonstrated for 2-phase (fiber and matrix) composites with linear thermoelastic and linear viscoelastic material models10 as well as non-linear damage models.11 In addition, a previous effort was made to extend MCT’s capabilities to handle decompositions of materials with more than two constituents.12

The primary goal of this study was to demonstrate the value of predicting initial matrix failure in textile composites based on the extension of MCT to an n-constituent capability. Where n is the number of constituents necessary to sufficiently expose the internal material response for accurate damage and failure predictions. To accomplish this, a meso-scale finite element (FE) model of a triaxial braided composite was developed. This model was used to calculate the volume-averaged stresses within the meso-scale corresponding to the same variables generated by n-constituent MCT. A matrix failure criterion was devised and initial failure predictions were then compared to experimental results reported by Ivanov et al.8 and Lomov et al.13,14 Parametric studies with the model have provided some insight to characteristics that a mesomechanics model must have in order to provide accurate results using this approach.

sec.title: Mesomechanics modeling of a triaxial braid textile composite
Description of triaxial braid and unit cell
sec.p:
A solid model of the triaxial braid indicating the unit cell used for this study is shown in Figure 1. This braid is known as a 1/1 diamond pattern triaxial braid with a 45° braiding angle. An uneven yarn spacing results in an ‘open weave’, meaning that open holes exist for single layers of fabric. Lomov et al.13,14 and Ivanov et al.8 have performed tensile tests on this braid in several directions utilizing acoustic emissions, X-ray imaging, digital strain mapping, and micrograph techniques to characterize the deformation and failure progression. They have also created detailed FE mesomechanics models.9 The geometric properties of the braid are listed in Table 1. Figure 1.
Triaxial braid showing a periodic unit cell (right) and braid terminology. Table 1.
Properties of triaxial braid14
Yarn properties
Braids Inlays
Fibers per yarn 24,000 24,000
Thickness (mm) Variable Variable
Width (mm) 4.21 ± 0.21 3.75 ± 0.16
Fabric properties
Braids (adjacent) Braids (open)
Yarn spacing (mm) 5.03 ± 0.24 9.25 ± 0.03

The concept of a representative volume element (unit cell) assumes that there is a basic translational pattern of geometry and response within the larger scale.15 Hence, a unit cell model must enclose a periodic domain (Figure 1) and utilize periodic boundary conditions. Some of the challenges of modeling this triaxial braid are described by Ivanov et al.8 and Lomov et al.9 A more detailed description of the present model was reported previously.16 It is extremely important to note that as far as MCT is concerned the details of the meso-scale model are not important, as is demonstrated later.

sec.title: Solid model and mesh generation
sec.p:
The solid model was generated using TexGen.17 The unit cell model created for this study represents a single layer of a triaxial braid within a laminate of many layers. In a real composite laminate fabricated using this material, some very complex interactions between layers will occur. Due to the open nature of the braid, the adjacent layers tend to ‘nest,’8 meaning that for a given layer of braid, the stacked yarn regions of adjacent layers tend to settle inside the open regions of that layer. This creates very complex yarn centerline paths and large variations in local fiber volume fraction along a centerline and through a cross-section.8 The kinematics of nesting is three-dimensional as it involves relative displacement of fabric layers in all three coordinate directions. A simplified two-dimensional schematic of nesting is shown in Figure 2, where the effect on fiber volume fraction of a laminate is illustrated. To allow the simple unit cell of Figure 1, no attempt was made to explicitly include geometric features of nesting in the meso-scale model. Figure 2.
Schematic of composite fabric layer nesting: (a) idealized un-nested fabric layers and (b) nested fabric layers depicting higher fiber volume fraction.

The inlay centerlines were assumed perfectly straight.18 The braid yarns thus undulate and were assumed to have the same cross-section shape (power ellipse) throughout the unit cell. To define a cross-section, the width of the cross-section (Table 1), the number of fibers in the yarn, the average fiber diameter, and the assumed average volume fraction throughout the cross-section were specified. Figure 3 shows a resulting FE mesh of just the fiber bundles and Figure 4 shows a FE mesh of the complete unit cell. Figure 3.
Finite element mesh of the yarn volumes within a unit cell. Figure 4.
Finite element mesh of the complete unit cell.

sec.title: FE model
sec.p: The mesh, described above, was imported into the Abaqus® FE modeling environment.19 Periodic boundary conditions were then applied to ensure that the behavior of the volume was that of a unit cell buried within a much larger material domain. Whitcomb et al.15 describe in detail such periodic constraint equations. In practice, an equation of constraint relates the displacement of a node relative to a reference node on the same face to relative displacement of the two matching nodes on the opposite face of the unit cell. For example, assuming faces 1 and 3 are opposing periodic cut boundaries of the model, then equation (1) is the constraint equation that eliminates the degree of freedom ui for a node on face 3 (F3) in terms of the corresponding pair node degree of freedom on face 1 (F1) and the two corresponding reference node degrees of freedom for faces 1 and 3 (R1 and R3) (1)ui(F3)=ui(F1)+ui(R3)-ui(R1)

Equation (1) requires that each of the two opposing faces (F1 and F3) have identical (periodic) node patterns. The complexity of the present model resulted in some deviations from identical node patterns. To overcome this, a more general approach was developed. Instead of directly relating individual nodes to each other, the displacements of nodes on one face are related to those of the corresponding locations on the opposite face. The element interpolation functions are used to define the displacement at the location as a basis for the constraint equations. For example, for an arbitrary point on an element face (F1P), the displacement of that location in terms of the displacements of the three surface nodes of the associated element is given by (2)ui(F1p)=[N1N2N3][ui(F1n1)ui(F1n2)ui(F1n3)] where Ni are the element interpolation functions and ui(F1nk),k=1,2,3 the displacements of the three nodes on the face of the element where point F1P resides. Substituting equation (2) into equation (1), the constraint equation becomes (3)ui(F3)=N1ui(F1n1)+N2ui(F1n2)+N3ui(F1n3) +ui(R3)-ui(R1)
In this scheme, only the reference nodes require matching relative locations on the faces.

The faces of the model parallel to the plane of the textile were constrained to remain planar but allowed relative motion to accommodate out-of-plane strain. Additional single-point constraints were added to remove any remaining rigid-body modes of deformation and thus prevent a singular system of FE equations. Finally, in order to simulate the experimental, macroscopic uniaxial load cases of machine, cross, and braid directions (MD, CD, BD), appropriate point loads were applied to the reference nodes which are coupled via the multi-point constraints to all nodes on their respective faces.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
For the triaxial braid modeled here, the material properties of the fibers and the matrix were taken from Miravete et al.20 and Lomov et al.9 and are given in Table 2. These properties along with a fiber volume fraction were the inputs to a micromechanics model21 that assumed periodic hexagonal fiber packing. By volume averaging stresses and strains predicted by the micromechanics model, transversely isotropic properties of the yarns were calculated for use in the meso-scale FE model. The overall textile composite fiber volume fraction was found through experiment to be 44%.9 Table 2.
Properties of the fiber and matrix
Fiber properties (HTS 5631 Tenax)20
Longitudinal modulus (GPa) 210
Transverse modulus (GPa) 72
Longitudinal shear modulus (GPa) 86
Poisson’s ratio, vLT 0.27
Poisson’s ratio, vTT 0.15
Diameter (µm) 6.9
Matrix properties (Epicote 828 LV/Epicure DX 5614)9
Young’s modulus (GPa) 2.7
Poisson’s ratio 0.4

sec.title: MCT and the n-constituent problem
sec.p: Two-constituent MCT has been described previously.10,11 Three-constituent MCT was investigated and shown to be useful by Key.12 The study presented herein represents the first attempt to assess the potential value of generalizing MCT to handle an arbitrary number of constituents for materials with complex heterogeneity, i.e. the n-constituent problem. Conceptually, MCT is a generalization of the continuum hypothesis where it is assumed that a continuum field exists at each point in the structure for every material constituent. For the linear elastic two-constituent problem (fiber and matrix), the average matrix strains can be calculated using equation (4). In equation (4), ϕm and ϕf are the matrix and fiber volume fractions, respectively, [I] the identity matrix, θ the temperature relative to a stress free temperature, {ε} the vector of composite strains, [C], [Cm], and [Cf] the composite, matrix, and fiber stiffness matrices, respectively, and {α}, {αm}, and {αf} the vectors of composite, matrix, and fiber thermal expansion properties, respectively (4){εm}=(φm[I]+φf[A])-1({ε}-θ{η}) where [A]=-φmφf([C]-[Cf])-1([C]-[Cm]) and {η}=([C]-[Cf])-1([C]{α}-φf[Cf]{αf}-φm[Cm]{αm})
The matrix stresses used in this study were computed using equation (5), where {εm0} are the stress free (thermal) strains in the matrix (5){σm}=[Cm]({εm}-{εm0})

In a textile composite, we can define constituents that exist at the meso-scale and are identified by local anisotropy and unique orientation of principal material coordinates. For example, in the triaxial braid, the inlay yarns and each set of braid yarns can be defined as three distinct constituents. The pure matrix pockets are then a fourth constituent at the meso-scale. Note that stress and strain tensors for the braid and inlay constituents can be decomposed using two-constituent MCT to obtain the average fiber and matrix stresses and strains within those meso-scale constituents. An n-constituent MCT capability was not available for this study, so numerical volume averaging of FE results was used to compute meso-scale constituent-average stresses and strains that would be identical to those of an MCT decomposition.

sec.title: Description of initial failure
sec.p: Model predictions were compared with experimental failure data collected by Ivanov et al.8 and Lomov et al.13,14 For the tensile tests described by Lomov et al.,14 acoustic emission, X-ray and microscopy were used to identify three critical strain levels. The first, denoted ε1, was defined as damage initiation. Physically, this initial damage was defined as the point at which a crack connecting several debonded fibers first appeared within a yarn.14 The interest here was in this first critical strain. For all three tensile load cases (MD, CD, BD), it was determined14 that the initial damage associated with ε1 was inter-fiber, intra-yarn transverse cracks. These results are in agreement with Masters and Ifju;7 where transverse cracks within a fiber bundle were also presented as the primary initial damage mechanism in triaxial braided composites.

For loading in the MD, these cracks were randomly located at the first critical strain level, but they were nearly all oriented at a 45° angle to the loading direction indicating failure in the braiding yarns. For BD loading, transverse cracks appeared at the first critical strain level at 90° and 45° orientations, indicating failure in both the orthogonal braids and the inlays. For CD loading, cracks oriented at ±45° and 90° to the loading direction appeared in a regular pattern. This crack pattern suggests that both sets of braids and the inlays were experiencing failure for CD loading at the first critical strain.

sec.title: Failure criterion development
sec.p: The failure criterion used here is an adaptation of the failure criterion by Mayes and Hansen11 who were following the work of Hashin.22 They assumed fiber-reinforced regions to be transversely isotropic with the x1 direction parallel to the fiber axes. The five transversely isotropic stress invariants can be written as11 (6)I1=σ11I2=σ22+σ33I3=σ222+σ332+2σ232I4=σ122+σ132I5=σ22σ122+σ33σ132+2σ12σ13σ23
Since Hashin22 began by choosing a quadratic criterion, the most general form of the failure criterion is (7)A1I1+B1I12+A2I2+B2I22+C12I1I2 +A3I3+A4I4=1

In equation (7), Ai,Bi,andCij are the functions of the ultimate tensile, compressive, and shear strengths of the composite. For the MCT-based criterion, the stresses of the constituents were determined for input to their respective failure criteria. To simplify equation (7), it can be argued that the term C12 was small23 and could reasonably be assumed zero. Furthermore, according to Tsai and Wu,24 the linear terms account for the internal stresses from constituent interaction, which is inherently accounted for in MCT. Thus, the resulting form of the MCT failure criterion11 was given by (8)A1I12+A2I22+A3I3+A4I4=1

For the triaxial braid studied here, initial failure was in the matrix, so the discussion here is limited to matrix failure. In the local material coordinates, the components of stress assumed important to initial matrix cracking included transverse tensile stress and longitudinal shear in the matrix. Therefore, the first invariant was eliminated from equation (8). The maximum and minimum transverse normal stresses are given by (9)σmin,maxtrans=σ22+σ332±[(σ22-σ332)2+σ232]12
Squaring both sides, equation (9) can be written in terms of the transversely isotropic stress invariants as (10)(σmin,maxtrans)2=14(I2±2I3-I22)2

Replacing the two terms in equation (8) involving I2 and I3, the criterion becomes T1±+A4mI4m=1 where (11)T1±={A2+m(σmaxtrans,m)2ifσmaxtrans,m≥σmintrans,m≥0max(A2+m(σmaxtrans,m)2,A2-m(σmintrans,m)2)ifσmaxtrans,m≥0≥σmintrans,mA2-m(σmintrans,m)2if0≥σmaxtrans,m≥σmintrans,m

The above accounts for three non-trivial cases with regards to the maximum and minimum principal stresses in the 2–3 plane. The two coefficients A2+mandA2-m are chosen depending on whether tensile or compressive transverse stresses dominate failure. The superscripts m emphasize that all stresses are for the matrix. Hence, equation (11) is physically based on the matrix transverse normal and longitudinal shear stresses in the principal material coordinates of a yarn; i.e. the components of stress most-closely associated with the observed failure modes. Note that although the matrix is assumed isotropic at the microscopic level (Table 2), failure in the matrix within the yarns is governed by the transversely isotropic character of the yarns. Clearly, the aligned fibers cause the failure response of the matrix due to transverse loads to be different from the response of longitudinal loads. This is why the transversely isotropic stress invariants were used in the above matrix failure criterion development.

sec.title: Failure criterion coefficients
sec.p: To implement the failure criterion, the coefficients A2+m,A2-m,A4m must be determined. In the original development of the MCT failure criterion,11 these coefficients were determined in terms of the corresponding constituent’s strengths by considering several different uniaxial composite load cases. Since the present failure criterion was applied to volume-averaged quantities of entire yarns within the unit cell, the unidirectional strengths based on uniform stress do not apply. Rather, the coefficients of equation (11) must be based on the in situ strengths of the yarns within the composite unit cell. In order to obtain these in situ strengths, the model was calibrated using test data specific to the triaxial braid. Three independent states of matrix stress that satisfy equation (11) are needed to determine the three coefficients. These stress states were obtained by volume averaging the yarn volumes in the meso-scale model that simulated test load conditions at initial matrix failure, and then applying two-constituent MCT to obtain volume-averaged intra-yarn matrix stresses.

sec.title: Homogenized properties
sec.p:
Basic validation of the meso-scale model of the triaxial braid was accomplished by comparison of homogenized effective properties of the unit cell with experimental results. The challenges in achieving realistic fiber volume fractions and good agreement with experimental data were described by Garnich et al.16 Results of this effort given in Table 3 indicate reasonable agreement between final homogenized properties and experimental values. Table 3.
Comparison between experimental properties and those predicted by the meso-scale model
Load direction Experiment stiffness9 (GPa) FEA stiffness (GPa) Experiment Poisson’s ratio9 FEA Poisson’s ratio
MD 32.6 ± 1.1 32.2 0.73 ± 0.06 0.63
BD 36.8 ± 1.8 34.5 0.07 ± 0.02 0.11
CD 15.9 ± 0.7 16.5 0.39 ± 0.03 0.32
MD: machine direction; CD: cross direction; BD: braid direction; FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Initial failure predictions
sec.p: Since only uniaxial tension test data were available, only A2+m and A4m could be calculated for use in equation (11). The failure criterion was only applied to the matrix regions located within the fiber bundles. Hence, three constituents were checked for failure within the unit cell; the matrix within the two sets of orthogonal braiding yarns and the matrix within the inlay yarns. The unknown coefficients, A2+m and A4m were determined through the simultaneous solution of equations resulting from known, independent, initial failure stress states applied to the failure criterion. For a CD loading, experiments revealed that the inlay yarns and both sets of braid yarns were experiencing damage at the first critical strain. For the BD loading, the orthogonal braid yarns and the inlays were both experiencing damage at the first critical strain. Since these two load cases have known failures occurring in two of the constituents, they could be used independently to determine A2+m and A4m.

Three versions of the model were constructed assuming 60%, 70%, and 80% volume fractions in all of the yarns. The BD and CD load cases were then independently used to calibrate the failure criterion for each assumed volume fraction. The criterion was then applied to the other two load cases to predict initial failure. The results of these calculations are summarized in Table 4. As required, the failure index corresponding to the load case used for calibration is exactly 1.00. Note that experimental confidence intervals for the failure indices are shown. Also note that once the coefficients in the failure criterion were determined through the calibration process, the corresponding directional strength of the yarns was calculated. For example, consider the value of 15.2 MPa reported for the longitudinal, composite shear strength for the 60% volume fraction case with CD load calibration. This strength implies that if the meso-scale model was loaded so that any one of the yarns achieved an average stress state of 15.2 MPa in pure longitudinal shear, and MCT decomposition was used to obtain the matrix average stress, the failure criterion would exactly predict failure of the matrix when the corresponding coefficients were used. Note that the strengths reported in Table 4 are artificial in the sense that they all correspond to the same experimental composite failure strain. As a consequence, the calculated in situ yarn strengths increase significantly with fiber volume fraction. However, the failure index predictions (bold numbers in Table 4) are insensitive to this change in the meso-scale model. Therefore, the actual magnitudes of the failure coefficients, though sensitive to changes in the meso-scale model, are not important. It is only required that the input quantities (matrix stresses) for the failure criterion scale appropriately so that the failure load level predictions (indices) become insensitive to the details of the meso-scale model. Table 4.
Failure indices for three versions of the model using the BD and CD load cases for calibration of the failure criterion
Yarn, Vf (%) Load case used Coefficients in failure criterion Corresponding composite (yarn) strengths Failure index at first critical strain
A2+m A4m S12 S22 MD load BD load CD load
(MPa−2) (MPa−2) (MPa) (MPa) Braid Inlay Braid Inlay Braid
60 CD 3.75E−03 1.09E−02 15.2 21.7 0.96 1.13 1.34 1.00 1.00
BD 1.90E−03 1.29E−02 14.0 30.4 1.03 1.00 1.00 0.71 1.00
70 CD 2.46E−03 7.14E−03 20.2 28.6 0.97 1.16 1.33 1.00 1.00
BD 1.29E−03 7.46E−03 19.8 39.4 0.98 1.00 1.00 0.73 0.96
80 CD 1.12E−03 3.81E−03 27.2 35.2 0.98 1.18 1.33 1.00 1.00
BD 6.01E−04 3.66E−03 27.7 48.1 0.95 1.00 1.00 0.73 0.93
Experimental confidence8 1.0 ± 0.31 1.0 ± 0.14 1.0 ± 0.21
MD: machine direction; CD: cross direction; BD: braid direction.

The importance of the above observation cannot be over-emphasized. The fact that smaller scale features of the material response can be assumed to scale proportionally to larger scale macro variables is fundamental to the success of continuum mechanics in general. In this case, the stress variation within a yarn volume is assumed to scale with the average stress in the yarn. It is only important that basic features of the meso-scale are present in the model to capture the local anisotropy of stiffness and strength, and relative interactions of the interwoven yarns. Then, the extraction of matrix average stresses in the local (yarn level) principal material coordinates provides a physically relevant basis for predicting the local initiation of failure as these stresses properly scale with load change relative to the actual matrix strength. Demonstrating this was the primary objective of this study.

The failure indices for the MD load case are well within the experimental confidence interval. However, for the BD and CD load cases, the predictions are often outside the experimental confidence intervals. In particular, the predicted braid failure for BD loading and inlay failure under CD loading are relatively poor. These predictions suggest that the assumption of equal in situ strengths for the inlay and braid yarns was not valid. While both the braids and inlays are fabricated from the same materials, they are fundamentally different when considering the yarn-level stress averages. The braids have undulations while the inlays do not, and the interactions that a given yarn has with the other yarns in the unit cell are quite different. Hence, the stress variations in the braids and inlays are different as well.

Three different approaches were considered to account for the differing stress variations. They include:
Decomposing the yarn volumes into smaller sub-volumes and the failure criterion could be applied to each of these volumes (MCT constituents). Utilizing smaller volumes reduces the stress variation within any one volume, thereby reducing the differences in behavior between the volumes. This would, in theory, improve failure predictions when using a single failure criterion for all yarn constituents.
Treat the inlays and braids as different materials with different in situ strengths. In this approach, two sets of failure coefficients must be obtained. Unfortunately, in order to obtain enough equations to determine these coefficients, both the BD and CD load cases would need to be utilized for calibration purposes.
Perform a statistical analysis of the meso-scale FE model results to establish a computational means of calculating different sets of failure coefficients for different meso-scale constituent materials (i.e. inlays and braids).

To rigorously pursue the first option, it would be necessary to know the location along a yarn where failure occurred. Since this information was not available, the second approach was pursued. The third approach is believed to be the most promising and is the subject of ongoing work.

To further justify the second approach, yarn-level initial failure envelopes for the braids and inlays were generated and are shown in Figure 5. Since no information was known for the failure behavior in compression, the transverse compressive strength was assumed to be 4.5 times the transverse tensile strength. This ratio is similar to that of some graphite-epoxy composites, but it is otherwise arbitrary. Therefore, the resulting failure envelopes in the second and third quadrants are hypothetical. Note that the axes of the envelopes are relative to the principal material coordinates of each yarn. These two failure envelopes represent yarn average stress states that produce matrix average stress states satisfying the failure criterion of equation (11). The two curves come from separate calibrations for the braids and inlays using the experimental failure strains for the BD and CD load cases. Figure 5.
Braid and inlay failure envelopes generated using the present failure criterion assuming a yarn fiber volume fraction of 80%.

The difference in the two envelopes shown in Figure 5 reinforces the assertion that the braids and inlays behave as two different materials even though they are composed of the same fiber and matrix. The differences in these two envelopes accounts for the differences in intra-yarn stress variations (in situ behavior) between the braid yarns and the inlay yarns.

In further pursuing the second approach, the previously described models were once again utilized, and two separate criteria were used to make predictions for the remaining (MD) load case. The results of the subsequent initial matrix failure analyses are presented in Table 5. Note that for the MD load case, experimental matrix failure only occurred in the braid yarns. Once again, while the strengths vary a great deal with assumed fiber volume fraction, the failure indices are insensitive to this parameter. Additionally, it can be seen that the MD failure predictions correlate very well with the experimental data. Unfortunately, the MD load case provides only one data point for validation. Table 5.
Initial matrix failure predictions and composite (yarn) strengths when using BD and CD for calibrations
Yarn Vf (%) Composite (yarn) strengths Failure indices
Braids Inlays
S12 (MPa) S22 (MPa) S12 (MPa) S22 (MPa) MD load BD load CD load
Braid Inlay Braid Inlay Braid
60 14.0 30.5 22.8 21.7 1.03 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
70 18.8 39.7 32.1 28.6 1.03 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
80 25.3 48.7 35.2 44.3 1.03 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
MD: machine direction; CD: cross direction; BD: braid direction.

For this braid architecture, the material principal axes for the textile composite are aligned with the MD and CD. Figure 6 shows the first quadrant of an initial failure envelope for biaxial tension in these principal directions. The points that are shown were determined by applying a ratio of MD and CD normal stress loads, and increasing the magnitudes of the loads until one of the failure criteria predicted failure. The location of matrix failure (braid or inlay) that was predicted is indicated on the plot. For comparison, the envelope for a maximum stress criterion is also shown. Figure 6.
First quadrant of a failure envelope for the triaxial braid under biaxial tension in the material principal coordinates.

Notice that a salient feature of the MCT approach is that it predicts the location within the meso-scale structure where failure is occurring. Another observation is that the failure criterion predicts significant strengthening of the textile composite against initial matrix cracking under biaxial loading, as is evident by comparison with the maximum stress criterion. While there was no data to validate this prediction, there are appealing physical explanations.

First, consider the significant increase in MD load required for crack prediction with the addition of CD load. In a pure MD load, the braid yarns are the location of matrix failure. The stress components in these yarns that make significant contributions to this failure were transverse tension and longitudinal shear referred to the local principal material directions for the yarns. These components were present with similar magnitudes because the loading is 45° from the braid yarn axes. Now consider that the shear stress caused by CD load will have an opposite sign to that produced by the MD load. So, adding CD load reduces the net shear seen in the braid yarns which in-turn increases the required magnitude of MD loading needed to induce matrix failure.

There is a similar explanation for the strengthening of the textile composite with the addition of MD load to a pure CD load. The experimental results revealed that for a pure CD load, both the braids and inlays were failing at the first critical strain. When a MD load is added to the CD loaded material, the same shear-reducing effect in the braid yarns is seen. This explains why the braids stop being a controlling failure mode as the MD load is first added. The inlays, however, are in almost pure transverse tension under a CD load. As MD tensile load is added, the braid yarns have a tendency to ‘scissor’ with a significant Poisson contraction transverse to the inlays. This compressive phenomenon, due to interaction with the braids, reduces the transverse tensile stress seen by the inlays, and explains the required increase in CD loading to cause matrix cracks within the inlay yarns.

sec.title: Parametric study of initial failure predictions
sec.p:
The MCT-based failure criterion described previously has low sensitivity of initial failure predictions to variations in the underlying meso-scale model. This is because each model provides a unique calibration utilizing matrix stresses that reflect the basic mesoscale architecture of the material and thus scale properly to provide consistent initial matrix failure predictions. To further illustrate this effect, parametric studies were performed. The results presented previously (Table 5) demonstrated this insensitivity to average fiber volume fraction in the yarns. Here, additional analyses were conducted for combinations of fiber volume fractions in the braid and inlay yarns. This alters the relative stiffness of the braid and inlay yarns, and the results are given in Table 6. Table 6.
Initial matrix failure predictions and implied yarn strengths for various yarn volume fractions
Yarn Vf (%) Composite (yarn) strengths Failure indices
Braids Inlays
S12 S22 S12 S22 MD load BD load CD load
Braids Inlays (MPa) (MPa) (MPa) (MPa) Braid Inlay Braid Inlay Braid
60 60 13.8 30.7 34.0 35.8 1.04 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
60 70 14.0 29.8 36.6 43.0 1.03 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00

MD: machine direction; CD: cross direction; BD: braid direction.

Once again it can be seen that the yarn strengths associated with failure criterion coefficients vary significantly with changing properties, while the failure indices are quite insensitive. This is due to the fact that the fundamental representation of the meso-scale architecture is unchanged and the relative magnitudes of sub-volume average quantities (MCT variables) are insensitive to these model changes. This means that different analysts will generally get the same initial failure predictions even if their underlying models differ significantly.

For further confirmation, additional analyses were performed where the calibration process was performed using meso-scale models where the braid yarn path was defined in three different ways. Smooth undulations of the yarns were defined using Bezier splines in one case and periodic cubic splines in another. The third variant in yarn centerline definition was a piecewise linear curve. These are plausible differences in modeling assumptions that might occur between different analysts. It was found that the in situ inlay yarn shear strength had the maximum variation of 6.7%, while the failure indices changed less than 0.1%.

Finally, the effect of FE mesh density on initial failure predictions was also investigated. Several iterations of the model were generated where the number of nodal degrees of freedom was varied using both linear and quadratic tetrahedral element meshes. It was shown that while the in situ composite strengths varied by a maximum of 13.4% over the range of meshes, the failure index for MD loading had a maximum variation of only 0.5%.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The primary goal of this study was to investigate the potential of MCT for predicting initial matrix failure in textile composites. To accomplish this, a meso-scale FE model of a triaxial braid composite was constructed as a basis for generating MCT stresses and strains at the meso-scale. A generalized plane strain micromechanics FE model was used to generate the unidirectional composite material properties assigned to the fiber bundles within the meso-scale model.

Following the premise of MCT, a constituent-based failure criterion was developed for detecting intra-yarn transverse matrix cracking. Volume-averaged stresses were computed for the three pairs of yarns and the matrix within the unit cell. Binary MCT decompositions were then used to analytically determine the average matrix stress states within the yarns. The failure criterion was applied using these matrix stresses. Initially, experimental results for the BD and CD load cases were used individually to calibrate a failure criterion and predict initial matrix failure in the other two load cases. This process yielded a mixed quality of failure predictions. This led to the conclusion that the inlay and braid yarns in the triaxial braid unit cell have fundamentally different in situ strengths due to their differing geometry and mechanical interactions at the meso-scale. This problem was investigated by applying two differently calibrated failure criteria; one for the braid yarns and one for the inlay yarns. The two criteria process yielded initial failure predictions for MD loading that were in excellent agreement with experimental results. However, the validation was effectively limited to a single data point. Further validation requires additional experimental data. Especially useful would be biaxial and compressive load case test data.

It was also shown that using this MCT-based approach, the initial failure predictions were extremely insensitive to many of the underlying meso-scale model parameters including yarn centerline path, assigned material properties, overall unit cell fiber volume fraction and FE mesh density. This is critical since the practical value of any failure prediction methodology is heavily dependent on the results being insensitive to the modeling details selected by any particular analyst.

Finally, as with any MCT-based failure criterion, a fundamental advantage is that it inherently provides specific information as to where damage is happening within the meso-scale during a structural-level analysis. In this case, matrix failure was predicted individually within the inlay and braid yarns.
